verses.verseStringB: In the name of Allah, the Compassionate, the Merciful.
Benignant, Hearing, Knowing God.ᵃ
These are the verses of the Book that makes manifest.ᵃ

verses.verseString: لَعَلَّكَ بَاخِعٌ نَفْسَكَ أَلَّا يَكُونُوا مُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Perhaps thou wilt kill thyself with grief because they believe not.ᵃ

verses.verseString: إِنْ نَشَأْ نُنَزِّلْ عَلَيْهِمْ مِنَ السَّمَاءِ آيَةً فَظَلَّتْ أَعْنَاقُهُمْ لَهَا خَاضِعِينَ
verses.verseStringB: If We please, We could send down on them a sign from heaven, so that their necks would bend before it.ᵃ

verses.verseString: وَمَا يَأْتِيهِمْ مِنْ ذِكْرٍ مِنَ الرَّحْمَٰنِ مُحْدَثٍ إِلَّا كَانُوا عَنْهُ مُعْرِضِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And there comes not to them a new Reminder from the Beneficent but they turn away from it.

verses.verseString: فَقَدْ كَذَّبُوا فَسَيَأْتِيهِمْ أَنْبَاءُ مَا كَانُوا بِهِ يَسْتَهْزِئُونَ
verses.verseStringB: They indeed reject, so the news will soon come to them of that at which they mock.ᵃ

verses.verseString: أَوَلَمْ يَرَوْا إِلَى الْأَرْضِ كَمْ أَنْبَتْنَا فِيهَا مِنْ كُلِّ زَوْجٍ كَرِيمٍ
verses.verseStringB: See they not the earth, how many of every noble kind We cause to grow in it?

verses.verseString: إِنَّ فِي ذَٰلِكَ لَآيَةً ۖ وَمَا كَانَ أَكْثَرُهُمْ مُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Surely in this is a sign; yet most of them believe not.
And surely thy Lord is the Mighty, the Merciful.ᵃ

verses.verseString: وَإِذْ نَادَىٰ رَبُّكَ مُوسَىٰ أَنِ ائْتِ الْقَوْمَ الظَّالِمِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And when thy Lord called Moses, saying: Go to the iniquitous people —
The people of Pharaoh. Will they not guard against evil?

verses.verseString: قَالَ رَبِّ إِنِّي أَخَافُ أَنْ يُكَذِّبُونِ
verses.verseStringB: He said: My Lord, I fear that they will reject me.

verses.verseString: وَيَضِيقُ صَدْرِي وَلَا يَنْطَلِقُ لِسَانِي فَأَرْسِلْ إِلَىٰ هَارُونَ
verses.verseStringB: And my breast straitens, and my tongue is not eloquent,ᵃ so send for Aaron (too).

verses.verseString: وَلَهُمْ عَلَيَّ ذَنْبٌ فَأَخَافُ أَنْ يَقْتُلُونِ
verses.verseStringB: And they have a crime against me, so I fear that they will kill me.ᵃ

verses.verseString: قَالَ كَلَّا ۖ فَاذْهَبَا بِآيَاتِنَا ۖ إِنَّا مَعَكُمْ مُسْتَمِعُونَ
verses.verseStringB: He said: By no means; so go you both with Our signs; surely We are with you, Hearing.

verses.verseString: فَأْتِيَا فِرْعَوْنَ فَقُولَا إِنَّا رَسُولُ رَبِّ الْعَالَمِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Then come to Pharaoh, and say: We are bearers of a message of the Lord of the worlds:
Send with us the Children of Israel.

verses.verseString: قَالَ أَلَمْ نُرَبِّكَ فِينَا وَلِيدًا وَلَبِثْتَ فِينَا مِنْ عُمُرِكَ سِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: (Pharaoh) said: Did we not bring thee up as a child among us, and thou didst tarry (many) years of thy life among us?

verses.verseString: وَفَعَلْتَ فَعْلَتَكَ الَّتِي فَعَلْتَ وَأَنْتَ مِنَ الْكَافِرِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And thou didst (that) deed of thine which thou didst and thou art of the ungrateful ones.

verses.verseString: قَالَ فَعَلْتُهَا إِذًا وَأَنَا مِنَ الضَّالِّينَ
verses.verseStringB: He said: I did it then when I was of those who err.ᵃ

verses.verseString: فَفَرَرْتُ مِنْكُمْ لَمَّا خِفْتُكُمْ فَوَهَبَ لِي رَبِّي حُكْمًا وَجَعَلَنِي مِنَ الْمُرْسَلِينَ
verses.verseStringB: So I fled from you when I feared you, then my Lord granted me judgment and made me of the messengers.

verses.verseString: وَتِلْكَ نِعْمَةٌ تَمُنُّهَا عَلَيَّ أَنْ عَبَّدْتَ بَنِي إِسْرَائِيلَ
verses.verseStringB: And is it a favour of which thou remindest me that thou hast enslaved the Children of Israel?ᵃ
Pharaoh said: And what is the Lord of the worlds?

verses.verseString: قَالَ رَبُّ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ وَمَا بَيْنَهُمَا ۖ إِنْ كُنْتُمْ مُوقِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: He said: The Lord of the heavens and the earth and what is between them, if you would be sure.
(Pharaoh) said to those around him: Do you not hear?
He said: Your Lord and the Lord of your fathers of old.

verses.verseString: قَالَ إِنَّ رَسُولَكُمُ الَّذِي أُرْسِلَ إِلَيْكُمْ لَمَجْنُونٌ
verses.verseStringB: (Pharaoh) said: Surely your messenger , who is sent to you, is mad.

verses.verseString: قَالَ رَبُّ الْمَشْرِقِ وَالْمَغْرِبِ وَمَا بَيْنَهُمَا ۖ إِنْ كُنْتُمْ تَعْقِلُونَ
verses.verseStringB: He said: The Lord of the East and the West and what is between them, if you have any sense.

verses.verseString: قَالَ لَئِنِ اتَّخَذْتَ إِلَٰهًا غَيْرِي لَأَجْعَلَنَّكَ مِنَ الْمَسْجُونِينَ
verses.verseStringB: (Pharaoh) said: If thou takest a god besides me, I will certainly put thee in prison.ᵃ
He said: Even if I show thee something plain?

verses.verseString: قَالَ فَأْتِ بِهِ إِنْ كُنْتَ مِنَ الصَّادِقِينَ
verses.verseStringB: (Pharaoh) said: Show it, then, if thou art of the truthful.

verses.verseString: فَأَلْقَىٰ عَصَاهُ فَإِذَا هِيَ ثُعْبَانٌ مُبِينٌ
verses.verseStringB: So he cast down his rod, and lo! it was an obvious serpent;

verses.verseString: وَنَزَعَ يَدَهُ فَإِذَا هِيَ بَيْضَاءُ لِلنَّاظِرِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And he drew forth his hand, and lo! it appeared white to the beholders.ᵃ

verses.verseString: قَالَ لِلْمَلَإِ حَوْلَهُ إِنَّ هَٰذَا لَسَاحِرٌ عَلِيمٌ
verses.verseStringB: (Pharaoh) said to the chiefs around him: Surely this is a skilful enchanter,

verses.verseString: يُرِيدُ أَنْ يُخْرِجَكُمْ مِنْ أَرْضِكُمْ بِسِحْرِهِ فَمَاذَا تَأْمُرُونَ
verses.verseStringB: Who desires to turn you out of your land with his enchantment. What is it then that you counsel?

verses.verseString: قَالُوا أَرْجِهْ وَأَخَاهُ وَابْعَثْ فِي الْمَدَائِنِ حَاشِرِينَ
verses.verseStringB: They said: Give him and his brother respite and send heralds into the cities
That they bring to thee every skilful enchanter.
So the enchanters were gathered together for the appointment of a well-known day,
And it was said to the people: Will you gather together?

verses.verseString: لَعَلَّنَا نَتَّبِعُ السَّحَرَةَ إِنْ كَانُوا هُمُ الْغَالِبِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Haply we may follow the enchanters, if they are the vanquishers.

verses.verseString: فَلَمَّا جَاءَ السَّحَرَةُ قَالُوا لِفِرْعَوْنَ أَئِنَّ لَنَا لَأَجْرًا إِنْ كُنَّا نَحْنُ الْغَالِبِينَ
verses.verseStringB: So when the enchanters came, they said to Pharaoh: Will there be a reward for us, if we are the vanquishers?

verses.verseString: قَالَ نَعَمْ وَإِنَّكُمْ إِذًا لَمِنَ الْمُقَرَّبِينَ
verses.verseStringB: He said: Yes, and surely you will then be of those who are nearest (to me).

verses.verseString: قَالَ لَهُمْ مُوسَىٰ أَلْقُوا مَا أَنْتُمْ مُلْقُونَ
verses.verseStringB: Moses said to them: Cast what you are going to cast.

verses.verseString: فَأَلْقَوْا حِبَالَهُمْ وَعِصِيَّهُمْ وَقَالُوا بِعِزَّةِ فِرْعَوْنَ إِنَّا لَنَحْنُ الْغَالِبُونَ
verses.verseStringB: So they cast down their cords and their rods and said: By Pharaoh’s power we shall most surely be victorious.

verses.verseString: فَأَلْقَىٰ مُوسَىٰ عَصَاهُ فَإِذَا هِيَ تَلْقَفُ مَا يَأْفِكُونَ
verses.verseStringB: Then Moses cast down his rod, and lo! it swallowed up their fabrication.
And the enchanters were thrown down prostrate —
They said: We believe in the Lord of the worlds,
The Lord of Moses and Aaron.

verses.verseString: قَالَ آمَنْتُمْ لَهُ قَبْلَ أَنْ آذَنَ لَكُمْ ۖ إِنَّهُ لَكَبِيرُكُمُ الَّذِي عَلَّمَكُمُ السِّحْرَ فَلَسَوْفَ تَعْلَمُونَ ۚ لَأُقَطِّعَنَّ أَيْدِيَكُمْ وَأَرْجُلَكُمْ مِنْ خِلَافٍ وَلَأُصَلِّبَنَّكُمْ أَجْمَعِينَ
verses.verseStringB: (Pharaoh) said: You believe in him before I give you leave; surely he is the chief of you who taught you enchantment, so you shall know. Certainly I will cut off your hands and your feet on opposite sides, and I will crucify you all.

verses.verseString: قَالُوا لَا ضَيْرَ ۖ إِنَّا إِلَىٰ رَبِّنَا مُنْقَلِبُونَ
verses.verseStringB: They said: No harm; surely to our Lord we return.

verses.verseString: إِنَّا نَطْمَعُ أَنْ يَغْفِرَ لَنَا رَبُّنَا خَطَايَانَا أَنْ كُنَّا أَوَّلَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: We hope that our Lord will forgive us our wrongs because we are the first of the believers.

verses.verseString: وَأَوْحَيْنَا إِلَىٰ مُوسَىٰ أَنْ أَسْرِ بِعِبَادِي إِنَّكُمْ مُتَّبَعُونَ
verses.verseStringB: And We revealed to Moses, saying: Travel by night with My servants — you will be pursued.
And Pharaoh sent heralds into the cities (proclaiming):
These are indeed a small band,
And they have surely enraged us:
And we are truly a vigilant multitude.
So We turned them out of gardens and springs,
And treasures and goodly dwellings —
Even so. And We gave them as a heritage to the Children of Israel.ᵃ
Then they pursued them at sunrise.

verses.verseString: فَلَمَّا تَرَاءَى الْجَمْعَانِ قَالَ أَصْحَابُ مُوسَىٰ إِنَّا لَمُدْرَكُونَ
verses.verseStringB: So when the two hosts saw each other, the companions of Moses cried out: Surely we are overtaken.

verses.verseString: قَالَ كَلَّا ۖ إِنَّ مَعِيَ رَبِّي سَيَهْدِينِ
verses.verseStringB: He said: By no means; surely my Lord is with me — He will guide me.

verses.verseString: فَأَوْحَيْنَا إِلَىٰ مُوسَىٰ أَنِ اضْرِبْ بِعَصَاكَ الْبَحْرَ ۖ فَانْفَلَقَ فَكَانَ كُلُّ فِرْقٍ كَالطَّوْدِ الْعَظِيمِ
verses.verseStringB: Then We revealed to Moses: March on to the sea with thy staff.ᵃ So it parted, and each party was like a huge mound.ᵇ
And there We brought near the others.
And We saved Moses and those with him, all.
Then We drowned the others.

verses.verseString: إِنَّ فِي ذَٰلِكَ لَآيَةً ۖ وَمَا كَانَ أَكْثَرُهُمْ مُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Surely there is a sign in this; yet most of them believe not.
And surely thy Lord is the Mighty, the Merciful.
And recite to them the story of Abraham.

verses.verseString: إِذْ قَالَ لِأَبِيهِ وَقَوْمِهِ مَا تَعْبُدُونَ
verses.verseStringB: When he said to his sire and his people: What do you worship?

verses.verseString: قَالُوا نَعْبُدُ أَصْنَامًا فَنَظَلُّ لَهَا عَاكِفِينَ
verses.verseStringB: They said: We worship idols, so we shall remain devoted to them.
He said: Do they hear you when you call (on them),
Or do they benefit or harm you?

verses.verseString: قَالُوا بَلْ وَجَدْنَا آبَاءَنَا كَذَٰلِكَ يَفْعَلُونَ
verses.verseStringB: They said: Nay, we found our fathers doing so.
He said: Do you then see what you worship —
You and your ancient sires?

verses.verseString: فَإِنَّهُمْ عَدُوٌّ لِي إِلَّا رَبَّ الْعَالَمِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Surely they are an enemy to me, but not (so) the Lord of the worlds,
Who created me, then He shows me the way,
And Who gives me to eat and to drink,
And when I am sick, He heals me,
And Who will cause me to die, then give me life,

verses.verseString: وَالَّذِي أَطْمَعُ أَنْ يَغْفِرَ لِي خَطِيئَتِي يَوْمَ الدِّينِ
verses.verseStringB: And Who, I hope, will forgive me my mistakes on the day of Judgment.ᵃ

verses.verseString: رَبِّ هَبْ لِي حُكْمًا وَأَلْحِقْنِي بِالصَّالِحِينَ
verses.verseStringB: My Lord, grant me wisdom, and join me with the righteous,

verses.verseString: وَاجْعَلْ لِي لِسَانَ صِدْقٍ فِي الْآخِرِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And ordain for me a goodly mention in later generations,
And make me of the heirs of the Garden of bliss,

verses.verseString: وَاغْفِرْ لِأَبِي إِنَّهُ كَانَ مِنَ الضَّالِّينَ
verses.verseStringB: And forgive my sire, surely he is of the erring ones,
And disgrace me not on the day when they are raised —

verses.verseString: يَوْمَ لَا يَنْفَعُ مَالٌ وَلَا بَنُونَ
verses.verseStringB: The day when wealth will not avail, nor sons,

verses.verseString: إِلَّا مَنْ أَتَى اللَّهَ بِقَلْبٍ سَلِيمٍ
verses.verseStringB: Save him who comes to Allāh with a sound heart.
And the Garden is brought near for the dutiful,
And hell is made manifest to the deviators,ᵃ

verses.verseString: وَقِيلَ لَهُمْ أَيْنَ مَا كُنْتُمْ تَعْبُدُونَ
verses.verseStringB: And it is said to them: Where are those that you worshipped

verses.verseString: مِنْ دُونِ اللَّهِ هَلْ يَنْصُرُونَكُمْ أَوْ يَنْتَصِرُونَ
verses.verseStringB: Besides Allāh? Can they help you or help themselves?
So they are hurled into it, they and the deviators,
And the hosts of the devil, all.
They will say, while they quarrel therein:

verses.verseString: تَاللَّهِ إِنْ كُنَّا لَفِي ضَلَالٍ مُبِينٍ
verses.verseStringB: By Allāh! We were certainly in manifest error,
When we made you equal with the Lord of the worlds.
And none but the guilty led us astray.
So we have no intercessors,
Nor a true friend.

verses.verseString: فَلَوْ أَنَّ لَنَا كَرَّةً فَنَكُونَ مِنَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Now, if we could but once return, we would be believers.

verses.verseString: إِنَّ فِي ذَٰلِكَ لَآيَةً ۖ وَمَا كَانَ أَكْثَرُهُمْ مُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Surely there is a sign in this; yet most of them believe not.
And surely thy Lord is the Mighty, the Merciful.
The people of Noah rejected the messengers.

verses.verseString: إِذْ قَالَ لَهُمْ أَخُوهُمْ نُوحٌ أَلَا تَتَّقُونَ
verses.verseStringB: When their brother Noah said to them: Will you not guard against evil?
Surely I am a faithful messenger to you:
So keep your duty to Allāh and obey me.

verses.verseString: وَمَا أَسْأَلُكُمْ عَلَيْهِ مِنْ أَجْرٍ ۖ إِنْ أَجْرِيَ إِلَّا عَلَىٰ رَبِّ الْعَالَمِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And I ask of you no reward for it: my reward is only with the Lord of the worlds.
So keep your duty to Allāh and obey me.
They said: Shall we believe in thee and the meanest follow thee?

verses.verseString: قَالَ وَمَا عِلْمِي بِمَا كَانُوا يَعْمَلُونَ
verses.verseStringB: He said: And what knowledge have I of what they did?

verses.verseString: إِنْ حِسَابُهُمْ إِلَّا عَلَىٰ رَبِّي ۖ لَوْ تَشْعُرُونَ
verses.verseStringB: Their reckoning is only with my Lord, if you but perceive.
And I am not going to drive away the believers;
I am only a plain warner.

verses.verseString: قَالُوا لَئِنْ لَمْ تَنْتَهِ يَا نُوحُ لَتَكُونَنَّ مِنَ الْمَرْجُومِينَ
verses.verseStringB: They said: If thou desist not, O Noah, thou wilt certainly be stoned to death.
He said: My Lord, my people give me the lie.

verses.verseString: فَافْتَحْ بَيْنِي وَبَيْنَهُمْ فَتْحًا وَنَجِّنِي وَمَنْ مَعِيَ مِنَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: So judge Thou between me and them openly, and deliver me and the believers who are with me.

verses.verseString: فَأَنْجَيْنَاهُ وَمَنْ مَعَهُ فِي الْفُلْكِ الْمَشْحُونِ
verses.verseStringB: So We delivered him and those with him in the laden ark.
Then We drowned the rest afterwards.ᵃ

verses.verseString: إِنَّ فِي ذَٰلِكَ لَآيَةً ۖ وَمَا كَانَ أَكْثَرُهُمْ مُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Surely there is a sign in this, yet most of them believe not.
And surely thy Lord is the Mighty, the Merciful.
‘ād gave the lie to the messengers.

verses.verseString: إِذْ قَالَ لَهُمْ أَخُوهُمْ هُودٌ أَلَا تَتَّقُونَ
verses.verseStringB: When their brother H∂d said to them: Will you not guard against evil?
Surely I am a faithful messenger to you:
So keep your duty to Allāh and obey me.

verses.verseString: وَمَا أَسْأَلُكُمْ عَلَيْهِ مِنْ أَجْرٍ ۖ إِنْ أَجْرِيَ إِلَّا عَلَىٰ رَبِّ الْعَالَمِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And I ask of you no reward for it; surely my reward is only with the Lord of the worlds.
Do you build on every height a monument? You (only) sport.ᵃ
And you make fortresses that you may abide.
And when you seize, you seize as tyrants.
So keep your duty to Allāh and obey me.
And keep your duty to Him Who aids you with that which you know —
He aids you with cattle and children
And gardens and fountains.

verses.verseString: إِنِّي أَخَافُ عَلَيْكُمْ عَذَابَ يَوْمٍ عَظِيمٍ
verses.verseStringB: Surely I fear for you the chastisement of a grievous day.

verses.verseString: قَالُوا سَوَاءٌ عَلَيْنَا أَوَعَظْتَ أَمْ لَمْ تَكُنْ مِنَ الْوَاعِظِينَ
verses.verseStringB: They said: It is the same to us whether thou admonish, or art not one of the admonishers:
This is naught but a fabrication of the ancients:ᵃ
And we will not be chastised.

verses.verseString: فَكَذَّبُوهُ فَأَهْلَكْنَاهُمْ ۗ إِنَّ فِي ذَٰلِكَ لَآيَةً ۖ وَمَا كَانَ أَكْثَرُهُمْ مُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: So they rejected him, then We destroyed them. Surely there is a sign in this; yet most of them believe not.
And surely thy Lord is the Mighty, the Merciful.
Tham∂d gave the lie to the messengers.

verses.verseString: إِذْ قَالَ لَهُمْ أَخُوهُمْ صَالِحٌ أَلَا تَتَّقُونَ
verses.verseStringB: When their brother ˝āliƒ said to them: Will you not guard against evil?
Surely I am a faithful messenger to you:
So keep your duty to Allāh and obey me.

verses.verseString: وَمَا أَسْأَلُكُمْ عَلَيْهِ مِنْ أَجْرٍ ۖ إِنْ أَجْرِيَ إِلَّا عَلَىٰ رَبِّ الْعَالَمِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And I ask of you no reward for it; my reward is only with the Lord of the worlds.
Will you be left secure in what is here,
In gardens and fountains,
And corn-fields and palm-trees having fine flower-spikes?
And you hew houses out of the mountains exultingly.
So keep your duty to Allāh and obey me.
And obey not the bidding of the extravagant,

verses.verseString: الَّذِينَ يُفْسِدُونَ فِي الْأَرْضِ وَلَا يُصْلِحُونَ
verses.verseStringB: Who make mischief in the land and act not aright.
They said: Thou art only a deluded person.

verses.verseString: مَا أَنْتَ إِلَّا بَشَرٌ مِثْلُنَا فَأْتِ بِآيَةٍ إِنْ كُنْتَ مِنَ الصَّادِقِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Thou art naught but a mortal like ourselves — so bring a sign if thou art truthful.

verses.verseString: قَالَ هَٰذِهِ نَاقَةٌ لَهَا شِرْبٌ وَلَكُمْ شِرْبُ يَوْمٍ مَعْلُومٍ
verses.verseStringB: He said: This is a she-camel; she has her portion of water, and you have your portion of water at an appointed time.ᵃ

verses.verseString: وَلَا تَمَسُّوهَا بِسُوءٍ فَيَأْخُذَكُمْ عَذَابُ يَوْمٍ عَظِيمٍ
verses.verseStringB: And touch her not with evil, lest the chastisement of a grievous day overtake you.
But they hamstrung her, then regretted,

verses.verseString: فَأَخَذَهُمُ الْعَذَابُ ۗ إِنَّ فِي ذَٰلِكَ لَآيَةً ۖ وَمَا كَانَ أَكْثَرُهُمْ مُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: So the chastisement overtook them. Surely there is a sign in this; yet most of them believe not.
And surely thy Lord is the Mighty, the Merciful.
The people of Lot gave the lie to the messengers.

verses.verseString: إِذْ قَالَ لَهُمْ أَخُوهُمْ لُوطٌ أَلَا تَتَّقُونَ
verses.verseStringB: When their brother Lot said to them: Will you not guard against evil?
Surely I am a faithful messenger to you:
So keep your duty to Allāh and obey me.

verses.verseString: وَمَا أَسْأَلُكُمْ عَلَيْهِ مِنْ أَجْرٍ ۖ إِنْ أَجْرِيَ إِلَّا عَلَىٰ رَبِّ الْعَالَمِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And I ask of you no reward for it; my reward is only with the Lord of the worlds.
Do you come to the males from among the creatures,

verses.verseString: وَتَذَرُونَ مَا خَلَقَ لَكُمْ رَبُّكُمْ مِنْ أَزْوَاجِكُمْ ۚ بَلْ أَنْتُمْ قَوْمٌ عَادُونَ
verses.verseStringB: And leave your wives whom your Lord has created for you? Nay, you are a people exceeding limits.

verses.verseString: قَالُوا لَئِنْ لَمْ تَنْتَهِ يَا لُوطُ لَتَكُونَنَّ مِنَ الْمُخْرَجِينَ
verses.verseStringB: They said: If thou desist not, O Lot, thou wilt surely be banished.
He said: Surely I abhor what you do.
My Lord, deliver me and my followers from what they do.
So We delivered him and his followers all,
Except an old woman, among those who remained behind.ᵃ
Then We destroyed the others.

verses.verseString: وَأَمْطَرْنَا عَلَيْهِمْ مَطَرًا ۖ فَسَاءَ مَطَرُ الْمُنْذَرِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And We rained on them a rain, and evil was the rain on those warned.ᵃ

verses.verseString: إِنَّ فِي ذَٰلِكَ لَآيَةً ۖ وَمَا كَانَ أَكْثَرُهُمْ مُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Surely there is a sign in this; yet most of them believe not.
And surely thy Lord is the Mighty, the Merciful.
The dwellers of the grove gave the lie to the messengers.ᵃ

verses.verseString: إِذْ قَالَ لَهُمْ شُعَيْبٌ أَلَا تَتَّقُونَ
verses.verseStringB: When Shu‘aib said to them: Will you not guard against evil?
Surely I am a faithful messenger to you;
So keep your duty to Allāh and obey me.

verses.verseString: وَمَا أَسْأَلُكُمْ عَلَيْهِ مِنْ أَجْرٍ ۖ إِنْ أَجْرِيَ إِلَّا عَلَىٰ رَبِّ الْعَالَمِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And I ask of you no reward for it; my reward is only with the Lord of the worlds.

verses.verseString: أَوْفُوا الْكَيْلَ وَلَا تَكُونُوا مِنَ الْمُخْسِرِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Give full measure and be not of those who diminish.
And weigh with a true balance.

verses.verseString: وَلَا تَبْخَسُوا النَّاسَ أَشْيَاءَهُمْ وَلَا تَعْثَوْا فِي الْأَرْضِ مُفْسِدِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And wrong not men of their dues, and act not corruptly in the earth, making mischief.
And keep your duty to Him Who created you and the former generations.ᵃ
They said: Thou art only a deluded person,

verses.verseString: وَمَا أَنْتَ إِلَّا بَشَرٌ مِثْلُنَا وَإِنْ نَظُنُّكَ لَمِنَ الْكَاذِبِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And thou art naught but a mortal like ourselves, and we deem thee to be a liar.

verses.verseString: فَأَسْقِطْ عَلَيْنَا كِسَفًا مِنَ السَّمَاءِ إِنْ كُنْتَ مِنَ الصَّادِقِينَ
verses.verseStringB: So cause a portion of the heaven to fall on us, if thou art truthful.ᵃ
He said: My Lord knows best what you do.ᵃ

verses.verseString: فَكَذَّبُوهُ فَأَخَذَهُمْ عَذَابُ يَوْمِ الظُّلَّةِ ۚ إِنَّهُ كَانَ عَذَابَ يَوْمٍ عَظِيمٍ
verses.verseStringB: But they rejected him, so the chastisement of the day of Covering overtook them. Surely it was the chastisement of a grievous day!ᵃ

verses.verseString: إِنَّ فِي ذَٰلِكَ لَآيَةً ۖ وَمَا كَانَ أَكْثَرُهُمْ مُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: Surely there is a sign in this; yet most of them believe not.
And surely thy Lord is the Mighty, the Merciful.
And surely this is a revelation from the Lord of the worlds.
The Faithful Spirit has brought it,ᵃ
On thy heart that thou mayest be a warner,ᵃ
In plain Arabic language.
And surely the same is in the Scriptures of the ancients.ᵃ

verses.verseString: أَوَلَمْ يَكُنْ لَهُمْ آيَةً أَنْ يَعْلَمَهُ عُلَمَاءُ بَنِي إِسْرَائِيلَ
verses.verseStringB: Is it not a sign to them that the learned men of the Children of Israel know it?
And if We had revealed it to any of the foreigners,

verses.verseString: فَقَرَأَهُ عَلَيْهِمْ مَا كَانُوا بِهِ مُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And he had read it to them, they would not have believed in it.ᵃ
Thus do We cause it to enter into the hearts of the guilty.ᵃ

verses.verseString: لَا يُؤْمِنُونَ بِهِ حَتَّىٰ يَرَوُا الْعَذَابَ الْأَلِيمَ
verses.verseStringB: They will not believe in it till they see the painful chastisement:
So it will come to them suddenly, while they perceive not;
Then they will say: Shall we be respited?
Do they still seek to hasten on Our chastisement?
Seest thou, if We let them enjoy themselves for years,
Then that which they are promised comes to them —

verses.verseString: مَا أَغْنَىٰ عَنْهُمْ مَا كَانُوا يُمَتَّعُونَ
verses.verseStringB: That which they were made to enjoy will not avail them?

verses.verseString: وَمَا أَهْلَكْنَا مِنْ قَرْيَةٍ إِلَّا لَهَا مُنْذِرُونَ
verses.verseStringB: And We destroyed no town but it had (its) warners —
To remind. And We are never unjust.
And the devils have not brought it.
And it behoves them not, nor have they the power to do (it).
Surely they are far removed from hearing it.ᵃ

verses.verseString: فَلَا تَدْعُ مَعَ اللَّهِ إِلَٰهًا آخَرَ فَتَكُونَ مِنَ الْمُعَذَّبِينَ
verses.verseStringB: So call not upon another god with Allāh, lest thou be of those who are chastised.
And warn thy nearest relations,ᵃ

verses.verseString: وَاخْفِضْ جَنَاحَكَ لِمَنِ اتَّبَعَكَ مِنَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ
verses.verseStringB: And lower thy wing to the believers who follow thee.

verses.verseString: فَإِنْ عَصَوْكَ فَقُلْ إِنِّي بَرِيءٌ مِمَّا تَعْمَلُونَ
verses.verseStringB: But if they disobey thee, say: I am clear of what you do.
And rely on the Mighty, the Merciful,ᵃ
Who sees thee when thou standest up,
And thy movements among those who prostrate themselves.
Surely He is the Hearing, the Knowing.

verses.verseString: هَلْ أُنَبِّئُكُمْ عَلَىٰ مَنْ تَنَزَّلُ الشَّيَاطِينُ
verses.verseStringB: Shall I inform you upon whom the devils descend?
They descend upon every lying, sinful one —
They give ear, and most of them are liars.ᵃ
And the poets — the deviators follow them.

verses.verseString: أَلَمْ تَرَ أَنَّهُمْ فِي كُلِّ وَادٍ يَهِيمُونَ
verses.verseStringB: Seest thou not that they wander in every valley,ᵃ
And that they say that which they do not?ᵃ

verses.verseString: إِلَّا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا وَعَمِلُوا الصَّالِحَاتِ وَذَكَرُوا اللَّهَ كَثِيرًا وَانْتَصَرُوا مِنْ بَعْدِ مَا ظُلِمُوا ۗ وَسَيَعْلَمُ الَّذِينَ ظَلَمُوا أَيَّ مُنْقَلَبٍ يَنْقَلِبُونَ
verses.verseStringB: Except those who believe and do good and remember Allāh much, and defend themselves after they are oppressed.ᵃ And they who do wrong, will know to what fInᵃ l place of turning they will turn bac

footnotes.note:
1a. The interpretation I adopt is based on the remark, which is traceable to I‘Ab, that      these letters are the names of the Divine Being. I take Δå as standing for LaΔßf, meaning      Benignant, sßn as standing for Samß‘, meaning Hearing, and mßm as standing for ‘Alßm, mean-      ing Knowing. I may, however, suggest another interpretation. These chapters speak in particu-      lar of the calling of Moses at Mount Sinai, Δå sßn may stand for Ô∂r Sßnå’, or Mount Sinai, and      mßm may stand for Moses; attention is thus called in these letters to the revelation granted to      Moses at Mount Sinai, which bears testimony to the truth of the Prophet. This is corroborated      by the plain statement made in the last chapter of this group, that the disbelievers called the      revelations of Moses and Mu√ammad two enchantments backing up each other (28:48).

          2a. The Holy Qur’ån makes manifest all that is needed for a right development of      the human faculties, and it also makes manifest the whole truth.

           3a. The Prophet was informed by Divine revelation of the doom of an evil genera-      tion, but instead of cursing it, he exerted himself heroically to save his people by bring-      ing about a mighty transformation among them, a transformation for which he was so      anxious that he is described here as almost killing himself with grief.

           4a. Such a sign was sent in the battle of Badr and again in the conquest of Makkah.      In the former place their chiefs were laid low, and in the latter they accepted submission.

          6a. It was the prophecies of their own vanquishment and of the predominance of      Islåm at which they mocked.

          9a. Seven prophets in all are spoken of in this chapter, and it is related how the      enemies of every one of them were exterminated in the ﬁnal triumph of the Truth. Yet to      give an indication of the fate of the Prophet’s opponents each prophet’s mention is      ended with the two attributes of the Divine Being mentioned here, the Mighty, the      Merciful, the ﬁrst of these indicating that Truth will, even now, be made to overcome all      opposition and the second that the dealing with the opponents of the Prophet would be a      merciful dealing. The Prophet’s opponents were vanquished indeed but they were not      destroyed and a reformed people rose again to power.

         13a. In 20:27 Moses prays to God: And loose the knot from my tongue. Here the      same idea is expressed by the words: And my tongue is not eloquent; see 20:27a.

          14a. The reference is to the killing of the Egyptian, as mentioned in 28:15. It is stat-      ed here that the people of Pharaoh charged Moses with a crime, not that he was      actually guilty; see 20a and 28:15a.

         20a. The circumstances in which Moses’ act of striking an Egyptian with his ﬁst led      to the death of the Egyptian are related in 28:15. There was no intention to kill the man,      nor did Moses use any weapon with which death could be caused. Rz explains ˙åll here      as meaning one perplexed, being unable to know what was incumbent on him. He used      his ﬁst against the oppressor, and death was simply accidental.

         22a. The Israelites were employed only in menial work by Pharaoh and the      Egyptians; it is this subjection to hardship which is here called enslavement.

          29a. The gods of the Egyptians were innumerable. There were the abstract gods, the      cosmic gods, the human gods, and the animal gods. Their god-cult may be summed up      brieﬂy in the words of the En. Br. (vol. ix, p. 51): “Truly it might have been said in      ancient Egypt, Of the making of gods there is no end”. Pharaoh’s claim to divinity among      a people who were willing to deify anything has therefore nothing strange about it.

      33a. See 7:108a; 20:20a, 22a.

           59a. The pronoun them refers to gardens and springs, etc., in general, and not to the      particular gardens, etc., from which the Egyptians were turned out. The heritage of gar-      dens and treasures was given to the Israelites in the land of Canaan, the promised land      ﬂowing with milk and honey.

           63a. The words i˙rib bi-‘a©å-ka-l-ba√ra are on all fours with the words i˙rib bi-      ‘a©å-ka-l-√ajara occurring in 2:60; see 2:60a. Elsewhere the same idea is expressed by      saying: “Strike for them a dry path in the sea, not fearing to be overtaken, nor being      afraid” (20:77); see 20:77a, 2:50a.

         63b. The sea had gone back, thus leaving a dry path (20:77) for the Israelites. The      meaning may be that each wave, as it receded, was like a huge mound. The word Δaud, it      may be noted, means a mountain, as well as an elevated or overlooking tract of land      (LL), and is even applied by a poet to a camel’s hump (LL).          82a. The prophets, being always conscious of their weakness, seek Allåh’s protection.      Expressions like this invariably indicate human weakness before Divine perfection, and      are not evidence of sinfulness. Compare Jesus’ confession of weakness in a similar strain:      “Why callest thou me good? There is none good but One, that is, God” (Matt. 19:17).

         91a. The making manifest of hell shows that it already exists, but is hidden from the      human eye, while on the day of Resurrection it will be made plain.

          120a. Wherever Noah is mentioned, only such of his people are spoken of as      having been drowned as rejected and persecuted him; see also 11:42a.

          128a. The word åyat, literally a sign, is used here to indicate the lofty building that      should acquire renown as a sign of greatness; see 2:39a. These lofty buildings were, no      doubt, used to terrorize others, as v. 130 shows that acts of cruelty and violence were      committed by ‘Åd, while they considered themselves safe in their fortresses.

           137a. The word khuluq sometimes carries the same signiﬁcance as the word      ikhtilåq, i.e., a fabrication.

         155a, see next page.

              155a. See 7:73a for Tham∂d. They are described in v. 149 as hewing houses out of      the mountains, and, as it appears from here and 54:28, the springs of water seem to have      been few, and access to these was probably specially guarded, so that they were open only      at particular times. For the she-camel, see 7:73c. ˝åli√ seems to have demanded that the      she-camel should be allowed to drink at such times. See 54:28, where it is stated that every      share of the water will be attended by the she-camel, or that she will have access to water      at all times when the others are allowed to drink. A similar demand as regards her pasture      is contained in 11:64 in the words “Leave her to pasture on Allåh’s earth”, followed by the      same words as those following this demand for drink: “And touch her not with evil”.           The word shirb signiﬁes either an act of drinking, or a share, or portion that falls to      one’s lot, of water, or a watering place, or a time of drinking. And in law it signiﬁed the      use of water for the watering of sown ﬁelds and of beasts (LL).

         171a. See 7:80a for Lot. The old woman referred to here was Lot’s wife.

         173a. See 7:84a. Stones were rained on them as the result of a volcanic eruption.

         176a. They are the same as the people of Midian.

           184a. The word jibillat (“generations”) means nature, quality, or property. But it is      also synonymous with jibill, and the lexicologists recognize the two words as conveying      the same meaning, viz., a great company of men, or nation, or people (LL).

          187a. Kisaf means a portion (R), and a portion of the heaven signiﬁes a punishment      from heaven. According to JB, kisaf means punishment.

          188a. It should be noted that the demand for the threatened punishment is always      met with expressions signifying that the matter rests in the hands of Allåh. Such state-      ments are really equivalent to saying that the thing will certainly come to pass.

          189a. Òullah signiﬁes a shade, or a covering, and the day of punishment is called      the day of Covering because it covered them with punishment.

      193a. The Faithful Spirit is the angel Gabriel, who brought the Divine revelation to      the Holy Prophet. The Prophet himself was known in Makkah as al-Amßn or the Faithful      one before revelation came to him.

           194a. The addition of the words on thy heart is to indicate that the Prophet’s heart,      being the receptacle of the mighty revelation, was no doubt truly responsive to the great      truths contained in it. The high morals and the broad humanitarian truths which the Qur’ån      contains give us a true picture of the great mind. This is referred to in one of the earliest      revelations: “And surely thou hast sublime morals” (68:4). The pithy but most beautiful      statement of ‘Å’ishah, the Prophet’s wife, than whom none was more familiar with the      recipient of the Quranic revelation, remains unsurpassed in depicting the character of the      Holy Prophet. When asked about it she replied: His character is the Qur’ån. She thus      intimated in brief words that all those wonderful pictures of moral sublimity drawn in the      Holy Qur’ån were pictures of the noble mind to which the Qur’ån was revealed.           196a. The prophecies relating to the advent of the Prophet Mu√ammad, as met with      in the Jewish and Christian Scriptures, are referred to very often in the Holy Qur’ån. The      statement made here is, however, more comprehensive: They are met with in all ancient      scriptures. See 3:81, where a covenant is spoken of as being made through all the      prophets of the world with regard to the Prophet’s advent; see 3:81a. There is a      reference in the next verse to the learned men of the Children of Israel in particular      because the Jews and the Christians had long been in contact with the Arabs. Such      references are of frequent occurrence in the early Makkan revelations, and there is not      the least ground for the statement that because of the mention of the learned men of the      Children of Israel, these verses must have been revealed at Madßnah.

          199a. Because prophecy plainly showed that the Arabs were to be the recipients of      the revelation; see Isa. 42:11: “Let the wilderness and the cities thereof lift up their      voice, the villages that Kedar doth inhabit”. In the Old Testament, Kedar, the son      of Ishmael, stands for the Arab nation. Hence earlier prophecy required that the ﬁnal      revelation should be granted to an Arab.

           200a. The meaning is that the Qur’ån was made to enter into their hearts by reason      of the convincing proof of its truth; but they rejected it, as the next verse shows.

          212a. The argument here is similar to that advanced by Jesus Christ when he said:      “And if Satan cast out Satan, he is divided against himself” (Matt. 12:26). The evil one      cannot be the source of the Qur’ån, for the Qur’ån calls to righteousness. See also      vv. 221–223 and 223a.

       214a. When this verse was revealed, the Holy Prophet, standing on Mount ˝afå,      invited every tribe by name, and when the representatives of all the tribes had gathered      together — among those assembled being also the Quraish and that inveterate enemy of      the Holy Prophet, Ab∂ Lahab — the Holy Prophet thus addressed them: “Tell me, if I      were to inform you that a great army in the valley lies in wait to make a raid upon you,      would you believe me?” “Aye!” was the reply in one voice, “for we have never found      anything but truth emanating from thy lips.” “Then,” said the Prophet, “know that I am a      warner to you of an approaching punishment.” “Mayest thou perish,” cried out the ill-      tempered Ab∂ Lahab, “was it for this that thou didst call us together?” (B. 65: xxvi, 2).

           217a. The Prophet is here told to rely on the Mighty, the Merciful, the very words      that are repeated at the end of almost every section of this chapter, thus showing that the      fate of the opponents of former prophets was spoken of simply to warn his own oppo-      nents. The attribute of mightiness is used to indicate the power to punish the wicked,      while mercy indicates the deliverance and triumph of the righteous, or a merciful dealing      even with the opponents.

           223a. The subject of v. 212 is reverted to here, and it corroborates what is said in      212a. The opponents of the Qur’ån would not listen to what is said in the Qur’ån — they      are far removed from hearing it, as stated in v. 212 — but they listen to what their lead-      ers in evil say.

       225a. That is, they pursue an aimless course, while the Prophet has a set purpose      before him, and it is to make men walk in the ways of righteousness.

           226a. The ﬁrst suggestion of the disbelievers was that the Qur’ån was the work of      the devil. That being shown to be inconsistent with its very nature and with the right-      eousness it preached, they said that it was the work of a poet. As against this they are      told that none of the characteristics of a poet’s work are to be met with in the Qur’ån.      The poet never leads his followers to a life of righteousness, while the Qur’ån was      bringing about a pure transformation in the lives of those who followed it. Again, the      poets say things which they do not practice, whereas the Prophet was not only a preach-      er of righteousness, but also an exemplar who translated into practice what he taught in      words. And the weightiest consideration of all is that the poets cannot utter prophecies      like those which are met with in the Qur’ån. It is to this that attention is called in the      next verse.

         227a. The passage gives a description of the true believers in general, a new state-      ment being introduced with illå (except); or it may refer particularly to the poets from      among the believers.
